newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Space crocodile, $500 Mercedes on Russia Fool's Day.
newsitem.headline: Space crocodile, $500 Mercedes on Russia Fool's Day.

text.p: An alligator bit a U.S. astronaut on the Mir space station, Russians were invited to join NATO to dodge the draft at home and a Mercedes went on sale for $500 on Tuesday as Moscow's media enjoyed their April Fool's Day jokes.
Itar-Tass news agency said the crocodile, called Gena after a Russian cartoon figure, was born from one of the quails' eggs being used for experiments aboard the station.
"Gena is growing rapidly and experts are considering transferring it to the international space station Alpha," Tass said, referring to the yet-to-be-launched orbiting station.
Many Russians failed to get a joke in newspaper reports that the government was selling foreign cars belonging to officials for as little as $500 apiece.
"These newspapers had to switch off their telephones today as people kept phoning in to find out the details," chief government spokesman Igor Shabdurasulov told a news briefing.
Russian officials want to stop buying foreign cars to help local firms and they plan to auction off imported models. But Shabdurasulov said no auctions had yet been scheduled.
Moskovsky Komsomolets admitted only a handful of its April 1 stories were true and it promised to pay two million roubles ($350) to those who said how many true stories there were.

Articles included application forms for individuals wanting to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation -- the newspaper said membership would help people to dodge the draft in Russia -- and a promise by Ukraine to hand over files on unidentified flying objects in return for rescheduling of Russia's debts.
Komsomolskaya Pravda said Russian and British scientists wanted to clone the abominable Snowman, found 20 years ago in Siberia.

"The Snowman is two metres (six foot six inches) high and its feet are 40 cm long. A young woman has already volunteered to give birth to the clone," Komsomolskaya said, promising free subscription to those who identify its April 1 spoofs.
